name: 3-amino-1-(4-chlorophenyl)-1h-pyrazole
Reason: 3-amino-1-(4-chlorophenyl)-1H-pyrazole has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a phenyl group, a chlorine atom, and a pyrazole ring. The phenyl group introduces a rigid structure and enhances pi-pi interactions, which can increase the melting point by approximately +30 to +50°C. The chlorine atom introduces a strong dipole moment, which can increase the melting point by approximately +10 to +20°C due to stronger intermolecular interactions. The pyrazole ring introduces a rigid structure and potential hydrogen bonding, which can increase the melting point by approximately +20 to +30°C.
